table.name: mstr_contacts
table.remarks:
Represents a single method of contact for a person, entity, place, or other contextually relevant association.
Note that there is a weakness in this part of the schema design in that contact information doesn't make sense outside of assignment to a person, facility, or entity, but such assignment is indirect through role assignments. This means it is conceivable that records in this table could become orphaned. At this stage, however, it doesn't seem worth it to denormalize the data to record the direct association.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Indicates the entity which is the owner or "controlling". There are a couple of ways this can be used. The first case is illustrated by the example of a managed entity and an staffing entity that is an individual. The owning entity in this case will be the managed entity for contacts such as the details of the person's office address, phone, and email addresses that is used in carrying out their duties as staff. The second case is where the entity is in a selling, purchasing, or banking relationship with the managed entity. In this case the owning entity is the entity with which the managed entity has a relationship since a customer, vendor, or bank determines their own contact details.

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A non-unique/non-key value used to display to users and external parties where uniqueness is less of a concern than specific end user presentation.

column.name: contact_type_id
column.remarks: Indicates the type of the contact record. Contact records store inforamtion of varying types such as phone numbers, physical addresses, email addresses, etc. The value in this column establishes which kind of contact data is being stored and indicates the data processing rules to apply.

column.name: contact_state_id
column.remarks: Establishes the current life-cycle state of the contact record, such as whether the record is active or not.

column.name: contact_data
column.remarks: Contains the actual contact data being stored by the record as well as associated metadata such as specialized data fields, mapping of the specialized fields to standard representation for data maintenance, display, printing, and integration.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_countries
table.remarks:
A listing of countries including currency symbology, official names, and other information concering the country from standards bodies and international organizations.
The table structure as it now stands is based on the data available at: https://datahub.io/core/country-codes

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interfaces.

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A friendly name for externally facing uses such as in postal addressing which maynot follow accepted international conventions for naming. Note that this is not a key value and has no UNIQUE enforcement.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_country_address_format_assocs
table.remarks: Establishes relationships between address format records and country records and allows recognizing an address format as the default format for the country.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: country_id
column.remarks: Identifies the country with with the address format is being associated.

column.name: address_format_id
column.remarks: Identifies the address format which is to be associated with the country.

column.name: is_default_for_country
column.remarks: If true, this format should be used as the default format for the country. There should only ever be one default for any one country_id.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_entities
table.remarks: Master list of legal entities with whom the business interacts. All legal entities are represented by this table, including the business using this application itself. The information stored in this record represents general information about the entity that is broadly applicable in all contexts which might use the entity.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks:
Indicates which managing entity is the owning entity for purposes of default visibility and usage limitations. This limitation primarily is evident in searches and lists. Explicit assignment of rights to entities, persons, facilities, etc. that are not the owning entity is still possible and those rights will prevail over the default access rules for non-owning entities.
There is a special case of owning entity where an entity is self owning. There may only be a single entity that is self owning and that, by definition, establishes that entity as the 'global entity'. The global entity has global administrative rights as well as allows access to those persons, facilities, and entities that it owns effectively making them global to all other managed entities. The global entity may be an actual business entity which essentially owns the MSBMS instance or it may a purely administrative construct for managing the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interfaces.

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A friendly name for externally facing uses such as in communications with the entity. Note that this is not a key value and has no UNIQUE enforcement.

column.name: entity_type_id
column.remarks: Defines the kind of entity that is being represented by the record and by extension the kinds of uses in which the entity may be used. Application functionality is determined in part by the configuration of the selected type.

column.name: entity_state_id
column.remarks: Establishes current state of the entity in the established lifecycle of entity records. Certain application features and behaviors will depend on the configuration of the state value selected for a entity record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_entity_banking_entities
table.remarks: Establishes an financial service provider relationship between an owning entity and a banking related entity. This record, or its children, will define the banking behavior when the transaction entity is the owning entity.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: entity_id
column.remarks: Identifies for which entity customer details are being defined. The terms in this record define the customer behavior for the entity defined by this field.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Identifies the entity that will use the customer terms when processing selling and receivables transactions with the entity identified in the entity_id field.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_entity_fulfillment_places
table.remarks: Establishes a relationship between an entity and a place allowing the entity to receive order fulfillment at the identified place; this is "ship-to" relationship. Note these places are used as the shipping places in external fulfillment transactions. For internal fulfillment transactions, the entity/ inventory/place relationship determines whether or not the place may receive units.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: place_id
column.remarks: Establishes that a place may be the destination of external fulfillment transactions for the entity.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Identifies the owning entity which may receive external fulfillment transaction inventory units at the place also identified in this record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_entity_inventory_places
table.remarks: Establishes one or more inventory relationships between a managed entity and a place.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: place_id
column.remarks: Identifies the place that will have an inventory relationship with the owning entity.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Establishes the entity which has an inventory relationship to the identified place.

column.name: receives_external_inventory
column.remarks: If true, this inventory may receive inventory shipments from third parties such as might originate from purchase order transactions. If false, this inventory may not receive inventory from external third parties.

column.name: fulfills_external_inventory
column.remarks: If true, inventory units may be fulfilled from this place, for this entity. If false, this inventory may not participate as a source of fulfillment to third parties.

column.name: receives_internal_inventory
column.remarks: If true, inventory units may be received into this inventory from other inventories managed by the system. If false, other managed inventories will not be valid sources to replenish stocks in this inventory. Transferred inventory would be an example of a transaction requiring the inventory to allow the processing of internal receipts.

column.name: fulfills_internal_inventory
column.remarks: If true, inventory units may be fulfilled from this managed inventory to another inventory managed by the system. If false, the inventory may not serve as the source of inventory units to other managed inventories. Transferring inventory out is an example of a transaction requiring this internal fulfillment ability.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_entity_person_roles
table.remarks: Establishes the relationship between individual persons and and entity. Note that for now a simple table with the entity, person, and the role assigned is sufficient for expressing the relationship, though in future it may be appropriate to have specific relationship tables like entity/entity relationships should the relationships not be containable in a single attribute describing the role.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: person_id
column.remarks: The person that is being assigned a role with the entity.

column.name: entity_id
column.remarks: The entity with which the identified person has a role. In many regards, this field identifies the owner of the record.

column.name: entity_person_role_id
column.remarks: Identifies the role being assigned to the person for the identified entity.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_entity_purchasing_entities
table.remarks: Establishes a vendor relationship between an owning entity and its vendor entity. This record, or its children, will define purchasing and payables behavior when the transaction entity is the owning entity.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: entity_id
column.remarks: Identifies for which entity vendor details are being defined. The terms in this record define the customer behavior for the entity defined by this field.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Identifies the entity that will use the purchasing terms when processing purchasing and payables transactions with the entity identified in the entity_id field.

column.name: diag_role_created

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_entity_selling_entities
table.remarks: Establishes a customer relationship between an owning entity and its customer entity. This record, or its children, will define sales and receivables behavior when the transaction entity is the owning entity.

table.name: mstr_entity_staffing_entities
table.remarks: Establishes an employee or contractor relationship between an owning entity and its employee entity. This record, or its children, will define the employee behavior when the transaction entity is the owning entity.

column.name: entity_id
column.remarks: Identifies for which entity customer details are being defined. The terms in this record define the customer behavior for the entity defined by this field.

table.name: mstr_entity_workplace_places
table.remarks: Identifies a specific place as being a valid option for person addressing, such as mailing, etc.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: place_id
column.remarks: Identifies the place which has a workplace relationship with the owning entity.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Establishes the entity which uses the place as a workplace.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_person_contact_roles
table.remarks: Associates individual persons with their contact data and includes an indication

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: person_id
column.remarks: Identifies the person which has the relationship to the contact information.

column.name: person_contact_role_id
column.remarks: Indicates a specific use or purpose for the identified contact information.

column.name: place_id
column.remarks: This is an optional value indicating whether the given contact information is associated with a place. If so, the place will appear here. This value will be null if not.

column.name: contact_id
column.remarks: A reference to the contact information which serves the given role for the given person.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_persons
table.remarks: Represents real people in the world. Ideally, there is one record in this table for each person the various entities interact with.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Indicates which managing entity owns the person record for the purposes of default visibility and access. Any person record owned by the global entity is by default visible and usable by any managed entity.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interfaces.

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A friendly name for externally facing uses such as in communications with the person. Note that this is not a key value and has no UNIQUE enforcement.

column.name: formatted_name
column.remarks: Contains a jsonb object describing the naming fields, field layout, and the actual values of the user's name. Note that the format will normally have originated from the ms_appl_data.syst_name_formats table, but reflects the name formatting configuration at the time of capture.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: mstr_places
table.remarks: places are system representations of real world buildings, such as office buildings, warehouses, factories, or sales centers. Note that a place may be associated with multiple addresses which can be assigned roles for different purposes.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: owning_entity_id
column.remarks: Indicates which managing entity owns the place record for the purposes of default visibility and access. Any place record owned by the global entity is by default visible and usable by any managed entity.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interfaces.

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A friendly name for externally facing uses such as in communications with the place. Note that this is not a key value and has no UNIQUE enforcement.

column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.
